title: Serbia - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 4 February 2021, an extreme-right group protested in Novi Sad, Serbia, against a closed anti-fascist event that was held near-by. No incidents were reported. [size=no report]
On 31 January 2021, people protested in Belgrade - Stari Grad, Serbia, in support of Russian opposition leader Navalny. [size=no report]

On 27 January 2021, a group of people protested in Belgrade - Stari Grad, Serbia, against a massive statue to a medieval ruler that was being unveiled, because the finances behind the statue are not transparent. [size=no report]
On 23 January 2021, people protested in Nis, Serbia, against reckless driving after two pedestrians, one of them a child, were killed in a car accident. [size=no report]

On 23 January 2021, fewer than 10 people attempted to protest in Belgrade, Serbia, in support of the Russian opposition politician Navalny. The protesters were ordered to disperse, which they did, by police who claimed that the protest wasn't reported ahead of time and was not in line with coronavirus guidelines. [size=fewer than 10]
On 22 January 2021, DS activists protested in Belgrade - Savski Venac, Serbia, against the party leadership. They are disputing results of the party leadership election. [size=no report]
On 16 January 2021, people protested in Nis, Serbia, against reckless driving after two pedestrians, one of them a child, were killed in a car accident. [size=no report]
URI: Association of Online Workers; Labour Group (Serbia)

On 16 January 2021, hundreds of freelancers, organized by URI: Association of Online Workers, protested in Belgrade, Serbia, after the state announced they would retroactively be charged taxes from 2003. [size=hundreds]

On 16 January 2021, approximately 100 people protested in Belgrade - Stari Grad, Serbia, in front of the Academy of Science and Art, after its president stated that Kosovo is independent. PO: Liberation movement publicly supported the protest. [size=approximately 100]
On 10 January 2021, three doctors marched through Belgrade, Serbia, in protest because of a very high death rate of health workers due to the coronavirus. [size=three]
On 10 January 2021, several dozen people protested in Nis, Serbia, against air pollution. The protest was organized by Dveri. [size=several dozen]
On 10 January 2021, people marched through Belgrade, Serbia against air pollution. [size=no report]
On 10 January 2021, around 50 Chinese copper miners protested in Bor, Serbia, demanding better working conditions. [size=around 50]
On 9 January 2021, several thousand people protested in Nis, Serbia, against reckless driving after two pedestrians, one of them a child, were killed in a car accident. [size=several thousand]

On 5 January 2021, in the afternoon, an unspecified number of people protested in Nis, Serbia, against reckless driving after two pedestrians, one of them a child, were killed in a car accident. In the evening, dozens of people joined the protest. [size=dozens]
URI: Association of Online Workers; Labour Group (Serbia)

On 30 December 2020, hundreds of freelancers, organized by URI: Association of Online Workers, protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, after the state announced they would retroactively be charged taxes from 2003. [size=hundreds]
On 29 December 2020, parents protested in front of a kindergarten in Zrenjanin, Serbia, because the creche group has been closed. [size=no report]

On 29 December 2020, several dozen people protested in Belgrade-Novi Beograd, Serbia, against a protected wetland being turned into a subway station. They tried to enter the hall where the city government session was taking place, but were prevented by security. [size=several dozen]

On 24 December 2020, approximately a dozen players of a local football club protested in Cacak, Serbia, because their health insurance or social security benefits had not been paid since the beginning of the season. [size=approximately a dozen]

On 24 December 2020, family of a boy who has died in a traffic accident protested in Belgrade-Zemun, Serbia, demanding stronger precautions from city bus drivers, as he was killed by a bus. [size=no report]

On 23 December 2020, around 1000 entrepreneurs protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia, demanding help from the government and a write-off of taxes and social security benefits for employees due to the coronavirus. [size=around 1000]

On 22 December 2020, around 700 prisoners went on a hunger strike in a correctional facility in Nis, Serbia, demanding better protection from the coronavirus. Approximately 20 family members gathered outside the prison to show support. [size=around 20]
On 18 December 2020, an unspecified number of people protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, against air pollution. [size=no report]

On 16 December 2020, families of people incarcerated in prisons protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia, due to many prisoners being infected with the coronavirus. They demanded early paroles for the groups who are high-risk. [size=no report]
On 13 December 2020, approximately 100 local citizens protested in Belgrade-Vracar, against construction on the only green surface in their neighbourhood. [size=approximately 100]

On 13 December 2020, several thousand people marched in a prayer procession through Belgrade, Serbia, for ''liberation of Serbia''. Several members of right-wing groups were present. [size=several thousand]
On 7 December 2020, activists of PO: Liberation Movement protested against a lithium mining company in Brezjak, Serbia, due to environmental concerns. [size=no report]
On 7 December 2020, activists of PO: Liberation Movement protested against a lithium mining company in Loznica, Serbia, due to environmental concerns. [size=no report]
On 2 December 2020, several hundred small entrepreneurs protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia, demanding help from the government due to the coronavirus crisis. [size=several hundred]
On 27 November 2020, students protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, demanding new university management and more input from students in running the university. [size=no report]

On 19 November 2020, several dozen citizens protested in Nis, Serbia, near the place on the railroad where a local teenage girl was killed by a train, demanding better security measures. [size=several dozen]
On 19 November 2020, farmers from a nearby village protested in Zitorade, Serbia, against a street being illegally built on their properties. [size=no report]

On 18 November 2020, activists of Women in Black gathered in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, to commemorate victims of war crimes committed by Serbs in Vukovar, Croatia, and demand those guilty be held accountable. [size=no report]
On 16 November 2020, patients of a tuberculosis clinic protested in Sokobanja, Serbia, against their hospital being turned into a coronavirus-only center. [size=no report]
On 16 November 2020, activists of Dveri protested in Nis, Serbia, against cutting trees in order to build a shopping mall. [size=no report]
Mass grave: On 16 November 2020, a mass grave was discovered near Raska, Serbia. The remains of 15-17 people are suspected to be those of Kosovar Albanians killed in the 1998-1999 war with Serbia.

On 12 November 2020, approximately 100 people protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, against measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus, like mandatory face masks, and potential vaccination. [size=approximately 100]
On 8 November 2020, an unspecified number of people protested against migrants and refugees as well as NGOs that aid them in Sid, Serbia, demanding restriction of movement for them. [size=no report]
On 7 November 2020, around 20 environmental activists protested in Baric, Serbia, in front of a car-part factory against air pollution. [size=around 20]
On 3 November 2020, local residents protested in Nis, Serbia, against new construction in their neighborhood which would limit their green surfaces and sunlight. [size=no report]

On 2 November 2020, around 50 restaurant and bar owners protested in Novi Pazar, Serbia, against the city restricting their working hours. The working hours were restricted as a measure to curb the spread of the coronavirus. [size=around 50]
On 1 November 2020, locals protested in Sid, Serbia, against migrants and refugees who are housed in a detention center in their town. [size=no report]

On 28 October 2020, activists of Women in Black protested in front of the Polish embassy in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia, in solidarity with those protesting in Poland against a total ban of abortion. [size=no report]
On 27 October 2020, local residents protested in Brezjak, Serbia, against plans to open a lithium mine. [size=no report]

On 26 October 2020, four men followed and severely beat a Lebanese migrant in Belgrade-Novi Beograd, Serbia. Anti-migrant rhetoric has been growing in Serbia in the previous days, with a demonstration demanding free movement of migrants and refugees being held the day before. [size=four]
On 26 October 2020, local residents protested in Belgrade-Zemun, Serbia, because their building has been without electricity and heat since the previous week. [size=no report]

On 25 October 2020, a protest against migrants and refugees was held in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia demanding migrants and refugees be contained in centers and not move freely around the city. Counter protesters were present, in solidarity with the refugees. [size=no report]

On 25 October 2020, a group of people protested in Novi Pazar, Serbia, demanding the head of the local hospital step down, because of how he handled the coronavirus epidemic in that city. [size=no report]
On 22 October 2020, students protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia demanding lower tuition fees as they are not attending in-person classes due to the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, several hundred workers and owners of tourist agencies protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia, demanding help from the government as their business have suffered due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=several hundred]
Srpski sabor Zavetnici; SD: Serbian Right

On 22 October 2020, several hundred activists of right-wing groups, most prominently Zavetnici and Serbian Right, protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, against a cultural festival connecting artists from Kosovo and Serbia. They attempted to enter the space which hosted the event but were blocked by police. [size=several hundred]

On 22 October 2020, activists of Women in Black protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, to commemorate a war crime from the 90's and demand prosecution of all war criminals, as well as better treatment of survivors. [size=no report]

On 21 October 2020, activists of an NGO that helps migrants and refugees reported they saw several police officers beat refugees who are sleeping outside of camps in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia. [size=no report]

On 18 October 2020, a group of Romani protesters gathered in Belgrade-Vracar, to mourn the killing of a young Roma boy 21 years earlier, and to draw attention to discrimination and violence Roma face today. [size=no report]

On 18 October 2020, a protest organized by a group of artists was held in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, in support of an exhibition demolished by a group of masked men earlier that week. [size=no report]
On 17 October 2020, several hundred people protested and marched through Belgrade, Serbia, against mandatory vaccination, face masks, and 'theft of children'. [size=several hundred]

On 16 October 2020, several dozen people protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, after the government recommended wearing masks outdoors at all times due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=several dozen]

On 16 October 2020, owners of bars and restaurants protested in Kragujevac, Serbia, because due to the coronavirus they can only work to 9pm, while other cities allow their service industry to work for longer. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, parents, students, and teachers protested in front of an elementary school in Belgrade-Rakovica, Serbia, because they want one of the teachers to become the principal, instead of the person currently serving at that position. [size=no report]

Property destruction: On 13 October 2020, a group of 15 masked men broke into a comic book exhibition, threw tear gas and destroyed the exhibits in Belgrade-Zemun. Authors of the exhibition said they received death threats on a national and ethnic basis and called the police about it, who didn't react.

On 12 October 2020, several hundred people participated in a vigil in Belgrade-Palilula, Serbia, lighting 1000 candles for 1000 days since the assassination of a Serbian oppositional politician in Kosovo, and protesting the fact that those responsible have not been prosecuted. [size=several hundred]

On 10 October 2020, parents who suspect their children have gone missing rather than died shortly after birth as they were told, protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, demanding the government uncover the truth about what happened. [size=no report]
On 10 October 2020, approximately 200 people protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, against the government and formed their own 'Parliament of free Serbia'. [size=approximately 200]

On 9 October 2020, teachers and parents of students protested in front of the elementary school in Belgrade-Rakovica, demanding one of the teachers becomes the school principle, rather than the current one. [size=no report]
On 7 October 2020, Women in Black activists protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, against the war in Nagorno Karabakh. [size=no report]
On 5 October 2020, several dozen students protested and blocked the road in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia, demanding lower tuition fees because of the coronavirus pandemic. [size=several dozen]
On 3 October 2020, students marched through Belgrade, Serbia, demanding lower tuition fees because of the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 2 October 2020, women's rights activists read out loud testimonies of women who were victims of gender-based violence in Novi Sad, Serbia, as a form of protest against violence against women. [size=no report]

On 2 October 2020, six members of Leviathan physically assaulted a man in Belgrade-Zvezdara and then made him apologize on video and post it on social media for 'comments he made about their organization' online. [size=6]
On 29 September 2020, students and professors of the Philological Faculty protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, demanding a new dean. [size=no report]
On 25 September 2020, former workers of several now-bankrupt companies protested in Nis, Serbia, demanding the wages which they are owed. [size=no report]
On 25 September 2020, drivers of a bus company protested by blocking traffic in Pozarevac, Serbia, claiming the contest for the city's public transport subcontractor was rigged. [size=no report]

On 24 September 2020, students marched through Belgrade, Serbia, demanding smaller tuition fees as they are not physically attending classes, and have struggled financially due to the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 19 September 2020, several hundred hikers and activists protested in Rakovac, Serbia, after a hiking trail was illegally fenced off as private property. They broke the chains holding the fence together in order to open up the trail again. Though private security was present, they did not intervene. [size=several hundred]
On 19 September 2020, several thousand people protested in Bor, Serbia, against air pollution caused by a copper processing plant. [size=several thousand]

On 18 September 2020, several dozen owners and workers in the service industry protested in Nis, Serbia, claiming it is impossible for them to work with current measures imposed because of the coronavirus pandemic. [size=several dozen]

On 15 September 2020, several dozen owners and workers in the service industry protested in Kragujevac, Serbia, claiming it is impossible for them to work with current measures imposed because of the coronavirus pandemic. [size=several dozen]

On 12 September 2020, supporters of the football club Partizan protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, in front of the National Football Association offices, claiming the Association discriminates against their club. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, approximately 15 people protested in front of the national television in Belgrade-Palilula, against the TV appearance of president Vucic. Several dozen supporters of the president counter-protested. [size=several dozen]
On 9 September 2020, activists of Women in Black protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia, in solidarity with protests taking place in Belarus. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, members of a union of a bus company protested in Pozarevac, Serbia, because of a contest for a subcontractor for public transport, claiming it was not transparent. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, around 300 members of the football club Partizan protested in Stara Pazova, Serbia, during a session of the National Football Association, claiming the Association discriminates against their club. [size=around 300]
On 7 September 2020, several dozen people protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, against mandatory vaccination against the coronavirus. [size=several dozen]
On 4 September 2020, an unspecified number of people protested in Zrenjanin, Serbia, against air pollution caused by a Chinese company. [size=no report]
On 4 September 2020, teachers and parents of students protested in Belgrade-Rakovica, Serbia, because, they claimed, the new principal is not qualified for the position. [size=no report]
On 3 September 2020, students protested in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, demanding guarantee that they won't be removed from their dorms during University Games next year. [size=no report]
Labour Group (Serbia); Journalists (Serbia); UGS: Union of Branched Trade Unions Independence
On 31 August 2020, journalists with UGS protested in front of the regional broadcaster in Novi Sad, Serbia, after more than 250 people were fired from the company. [size=no report]

On 29 August 2020, approximately 100 cars participated in a vehicular protest through Belgrade, Serbia, in support of those protesting against the Religious Freedom Law in Montenegro. The Serbian Orthodox Church feels unfairly targeted by this law. [size=approximately 100 cars]
On 28 August 2020, farmers protested in Raca, Serbia, against consolidation of agricultural land. [size=no report]
On 27 August 2020, around 30 people protested in Novi Pazar, Serbia, blaming corruption of the management of local hospital for a very high number of deaths from the coronavirus. [size=around 30]

On 25 August 2020, representatives of the tourist industry and rent-a-car companies protested in Kragujevac, Serbia, demanding help from the state because their businesses were badly affected by the coronavirus pandemic. This was a coordinated protest in four cities. [size=no report]

On 25 August 2020, approximately 200 representatives of the tourist industry and rent-a-car companies protested in Nis, Serbia, demanding help from the state because their businesses were badly affected by the coronavirus pandemic. This was a coordinated protest in four cities. [size=approximately 200]

On 25 August 2020, representatives of the tourist industry and rent-a-car companies protested in Belgrade, Serbia, demanding help from the state because their businesses were badly affected by the coronavirus pandemic. This was a coordinated protest in four cities. [size=no report]

On 25 August 2020, representatives of the tourist industry and rent-a-car companies protested in Novi Sad, Serbia, demanding help from the state because their businesses were badly affected by the coronavirus pandemic. This was a coordinated protest in four cities. [size=no report]
Journalists (Serbia); Labour Group (Serbia); UGS: Union of Branched Trade Unions Independence

On 24 August 2020, journalists, members of Union of Branched Trade Unions Independence, protested in Novi Sad, Serbia, after the state regional broadcasting corporation announced it would be laying off 200 people. [size=no report]

On 23 August 2020, several dozen cars started a procession from Belgrade, Serbia to Montenegro, as a form of vehicular protest against the Montenegrin Religious Freedom Law. The Serbian Orthodox Church feels unfairly targeted by this law. [size=several dozen cars]
On 22 August 2020, several dozen people protested in Smederevo, Serbia, due to air pollution. [size=several dozen]
On 21 August 2020, local residents protested in Zrenjanin, Serbia, against bad smells coming from a near-by rendering plant. [size=no report]

On 19 August 2020, around 30 workers from India working in Serbia protested in Kraljevo, Serbia, because the company they work for owes them several salaries and they are unable to go home due to coronavirus-related travel restrictions. [size=around 30]
YIHR: Youth Initiative for Human Rights

On 14 August 2020, Youth Initiative for Human Rights protested in front of the Belarus embassy in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia in solidarity with anti-government protests taking place in Belarus. [size=no report]

On 14 August 2020, approximately 100 protesters marched through Novi Sad, Serbia, 'against violence' after an oppositional activist was physically attacked in that city several days before. [size=approximately 100]
On 11 August 2020, workers of a company protested in Odzaci, Serbia, demanding PPE and epidemiologic measures after two of their co-workers died of the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 10 August 2020, approximately 100 people protested in Novi Pazar, Serbia, demanding the director of the local hospital step down. Novi Pazar has been hit very hard by the coronavirus pandemic. [size=approximately 100]
On 8 August 2020, more than 100 cars and motorcycles participated in a vehicular protest against bad smells coming from a rendering plant in Zrenjanin, Serbia. [size=more than 100 vehicles]

On 4 August 2020, approximately 30 workers from India, temporarily working in Serbia protested in Kraljevo, Serbia, because their wages have been delayed and they are unable to leave due to coronavirus. [size=approximately 30]

On 3 August 2020, several dozen protesters, led by DJB, protested while the newly elected parliament was sworn in in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia. They claimed the elections were stolen and threw eggs and tomatoes at the parliament building. [size=several dozen]

On 2 August 2020, approximately 100 people joined an anti-government protest organized by DJB in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia, the evening before the newly-elected parliament was sworn in. The organizers called the elections 'fraudulent.' [size=approximately 100]
On 1 August 2020, local residents protested in Zrenjanin, Serbia, against smells coming from a rendering plant. [size=no report]
On 30 July 2020, during a city parliament session, a group of activists protested in Belgrade-Novi Beograd, Serbia, against the cutting of trees in Belgrade's biggest park. [size=no report]

On 29 July 2020, several dozen residents protested in Vlasotince, Serbia, demanding local authorities allow swimming in the local river, which has been prohibited as a measure to stop the spread of the coronavirus. [size=several dozen]

On 28 July 2020, around 50 citizens protested in Novi Pazar, Serbia, a town hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic. They demanded local official take responsibility for the hight number of deaths and the dismissal of the crisis headquarters. [size=around 50]
Property destruction: On 28 July 2020, the official vehicle of the 'Glas Podrinja', a local oppositional magazine, was damaged in Sabac, Serbia.
USS: United Unions of Serbia Unity; Farmers (Serbia)
On 28 July 2020, farmers who are members of USS protested in Belgrade-Novi Beograd, Serbia, against the import of tomatoes. [size=no report]

On 25 July 2020, approximately 50 people protested in Novi Pazar, Serbia, a city that has been hit hard by the coronavirus, demanding a new crisis headquarters, that the hospital coordinator step down, and more transparency in spending donations which they had received. [size=approximately 50]
On 25 July 2020, local residents protested in Zrenjanin, Serbia, against the smells coming from a rendering plant. [size=no report]

On 25 July 2020, around 20 train drivers protested in Sabac, Serbia, demanding the immediate release of their colleague who had been detained after a traffic accident involving a car and the train he was operating. [size=around 20]

On 22 July 2020, Roof Overhead activists protested in Belgrade-Vozdovac, Serbia, against 'police repression and brutality'. They also demanded the immediate release of all those arrested during demonstrations that broke out after the government announced it would be reintroducing lockdown measure to fight the coronavirus. [size=no report]
On 21 July 2020, local residents protested in Nis, Serbia, after asphalt on a newly-reconstructed street fell apart after first rainfall, demanding a new reconstruction. [size=no report]

On 20 July 2020, several dozen Roof Overhead activists protested in Novi Sad, Serbia, against 'police repression and brutality'. They also demanded the immediate release of all those arrested during demonstrations that broke out after the government announced it would be reintroducing lockdown measure to fight the coronavirus. [size=several dozen]
On 18 July 2020, local residents protested in Belgrade-Vracar, Serbia, because a part of the public park was fenced off as private property. [size=no report]
On 18 July 2020, local residents protested in Zrenjanin, Serbia, against the smells coming from a rendering plant. [size=no report]

On 16 July 2020, approximately 200 protesters gathered in Novi Sad, Serbia, against 'police brutality and repression' after it became known that police in that city severely beat an autistic young man who was cycling past the demonstrations that took place over the reintroduction of coronavirus measures. The protest was organized by Roof Overhead. [size=approximately 200]

On 16 July 2020, around 20 activists of Roof Overhead protested in Belgrade-Savski Venac, Serbia, demanding all those arrested during the demonstrations that took place after the government announced the reintroduction of coronavirus measures. Several of those arrested are Roof Overhead activists. [size=around 20]

On 15 July 2020, several dozen protesters gathered in Belgrade-Stari Grad, Serbia against the government. Demonstrations in several cities started when the president announced stronger measures against the coronavirus and a weekend-long curfew, weeks after the measures were dropped in order to hold election. [size=several dozen]
USS: United Unions of Serbia Unity; Labour Group (Serbia)

On 15 July 2020, members of USS protested in front of the Ministry of Agriculture in Belgrade-Novi Beograd, Serbia, over the prices of certain agricultural products, which they claim are too low. [size=no report]

On 15 July 2020, around 20 protesters gathered in Cacak, Serbia against the government. On 14 July 2020, around 20 people protested in Cacak, Serbia, demanding someone take responsibility for the death of two men from that city who died of the coronavirus. The two brothers fell ill and died just after measures were dropped and city hospital stopped providing tests for the virus. [size=around 20]

On 14 July 2020, protesters gathered in front of the city central jail in Belgrade-Vozdovac, Serbia, demanding the immediate release of those arrested during the protests that broke out after the government announced stricter lockdown measures against the coronavirus.
